Issues.Title: Narrow the scope of the CUSTOM_ELEMENTS_SCHEMA schema
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

`@angular/core` (and `@angular/compiler`?)

### Description

Currently, when using custom elements (e.g., Web Components) within an Angular application, developers must declare CUSTOM_ELEMENTS_SCHEMA either at the module level (e.g., NgModule.schemas) or component level (@Component.schemas). This global declaration effectively tells the Angular compiler to ignore any unknown elements within the entire scope, which can lead to a less strict template validation than desired, as it disables validation for all unknown elements, even those not intended to be custom elements.

It is of course possible to create small components that have the CUSTOM_ELEMENTS_SCHEMA. However, it is more difficult to maintain the quality of those templates over time. A pull request with only a HTML change would not show the schema that applies.

This proposal aims to introduce a mechanism to apply the CUSTOM_ELEMENTS_SCHEMA only to a specific, localized scope within an Angular template, leveraging the new @-prefixed control flow syntax. This would allow developers to precisely define where custom elements are expected, thus maintaining stricter template validation for the rest of the template and improving developer experience by reducing unnecessary global declarations.

### Proposed solution

I would like to propose a syntax to allow custom elements within a defined scope of a component template.

The syntax would look like this:
```HTML
@schema(CUSTOM_ELEMENTS_SCHEMA) {
<fluent-card class="custom">
    <fluent-progress value="64"></fluent-progress>
    @schema(ANGULAR_DEFAULT_SCHEMA) {
        <app-example>This component should still exist</app-example>
    }
</fluent-card>
}
```
This way, you can define blocks within a template where a schema applies. In this proposal ANGULAR_DEFAULT_SCHEMA would refer to the schema that Angular applies by default if no other schema is defined. The example shows how you can nest this syntax to apply different schema's to nested HTML in the template.

The schema should be provided as a value.

By defining the schema within the template, it's less likely that the applied schema is overlooked, and it introduces enough flexibility to still apply validation where that is desired.

### Alternatives considered

Having block scopes makes the template more verbose. I did consider having element scoped schema's, for example:
```HTML
<fluent-card class="custom" @schema="CUSTOM_ELEMENTS_SCHEMA">
    <fluent-progress value="64" @schema="CUSTOM_ELEMENTS_SCHEMA" />
    <app-example>This component should still exist</app-example>
</fluent-card>
```

But having the block scope notation leaves no questions about the scope of the schema.

Alternatively I did consider a notation like the one below, but I feel it's just difficult to read (and the element name could become a variable, with potential complex results):

```HTML
<ng-element ngElementName="fluent-card" class="custom">
    <app-example>This component still exists</app-example>
</ng-element>
```

Optionally it could be nice to also have this feature as a structural directive (*ngSchema="CUSTOM_ELEMENTS_SCHEMA"), similar to how `@if` has an *ngIf alternative. But since there is no *ngLet, I considered to leave this scenario out of the proposal.

---

Alternatively a more adaptable schema could be considered:
```
schemas: [REGEX_SCHEMA(/^fluent\-/i)]
```
However, this could lead to complex regular expressions or a regex that could degrade performance.

---

It is of course possible to create small components that have the CUSTOM_ELEMENTS_SCHEMA. However, it is more difficult to maintain the quality of those templates over time. A pull request with only a HTML change would not show the schema that applies, leading the reviewer to assume that the used element names are correct.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Narrow the scope of the CUSTOM_ELEMENTS_SCHEMA schema" (#62484)

Issues.Title: Challenges updating older Angular projects: overwhelming warnings and lack of clear upgrade path for real-world developers
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

upgrade

### Description

Hi Angular team,

### I wanted to share a challenge many developers face when revisiting older Angular projects:

## Context:
Developers often donâ€™t read Angular documentation daily, especially if theyâ€™re maintaining stable projects that havenâ€™t needed updates for years. When returning to projects made with older Angular versions (e.g., Angular 7), we encounter:

A flood of warnings during npm install or ng serve, including outdated dependencies and peer mismatches.

Difficulty understanding which warnings need immediate action vs. what can be safely ignored.

Uncertainty about whether to upgrade step-by-step or create a new project and manually migrate code.

## The problem:
While experienced developers can figure this out, itâ€™s time-consuming and overwhelming â€” and it creates a barrier for maintaining older Angular projects.

### Proposed solution

### Suggestions for improvement:

Provide a clearer, more automated upgrade path for old projects â€” e.g., a command like ng upgrade-old-project that can handle common migration steps.

Enhance ng update or ng serve to offer a summary of actionable steps when it detects outdated versions, instead of scattered warnings.

### Alternatives considered

Share concise, user-friendly guides or videos to help developers quickly get up to speed on upgrading without reading extensive documentation.

I believe making this easier would help many teams keep long-lived Angular projects healthy and maintainable.

Thank you for your hard work and for considering this suggestion!
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Challenges updating older Angular projects: overwhelming warnings and lack of clear upgrade path for real-world developers" (#62483)

Issues.Title: Unexpected `debug_node.mjs` bundled in production builds
Issues.Body: ### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug? core ### Is this a regression? Yes ### Description After migrating to Angular 20 I noticed that my main JS chunk increased in size with about 103kb (just to clarify that I mean minified size when I'm mentioning file sizes here). After analyzing the bundle with esbuild I found out that there's this new module `debug_node.mjs` inside which takes big portion of the chunk. I also noticed that the size of this module varies depending on the size of the application. On my application it's ~103kb while on a fresh Angular project it's 65kb. After some digging I came to the conclusion that this module is not supposed to be included in production builds but only in development builds. Example of bundle analysis of a fresh app bootstrapped with Angular CLI 20.0.5: Example from my app: ### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug Just use `ng new` with the latest Angualr CLI ### Please provide the exception or error you saw ```true ``` ### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`) ```true Angular CLI: 20.0.5 Node: 22.17.0 Package Manager: npm 10.9.2 OS: linux x64 Angular: ... Package Version ------------------------------------------------------ @angular-devkit/architect 0.2000.5 (cli-only) @angular-devkit/core 20.0.5 (cli-only) @angular-devkit/schematics 20.0.5 (cli-only) @schematics/angular 20.0.5 (cli-only) ``` ### Anything else? Before creating the ticket I tried deleting `node_modules`, `dist` and `.angular` folders, then running again `npm install` and `ng build`. The issue still persists so it's not related to npm cache or angualr cache.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Unexpected `debug_node.mjs` bundled in production builds" (#62481)

Issues.Title: build: update dependency aspect_rules_ts to v3.6.2 (20.1.x)
Issues.Body:
This PR contains the following updates:

| Package | Type | Update | Change |
|---|---|---|---|
| [aspect_rules_ts](https://redirect.github.com/aspect-build/rules_ts) | http_archive | patch | `v3.6.0` -> `v3.6.2` |

---

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>aspect-build/rules_ts (aspect_rules_ts)</summary>

### [`v3.6.2`](https://redirect.github.com/aspect-build/rules_ts/releases/tag/v3.6.2)

[Compare Source](https://redirect.github.com/aspect-build/rules_ts/compare/v3.6.0...v3.6.2)

#### Using [Bzlmod]:

Add to your `MODULE.bazel` file:

```starlark
bazel_dep(name = "aspect_rules_ts", version = "3.6.2")

rules_ts_ext = use_extension("@​aspect_rules_ts//ts:extensions.bzl", "ext", dev_dependency = True)

rules_ts_ext.deps(
    ts_version_from = "//:package.json",
)

use_repo(rules_ts_ext, "npm_typescript")
```

[Bzlmod]: https://bazel.build/build/bzlmod

#### Using legacy WORKSPACE

Paste this snippet into your `WORKSPACE` file:

```starlark
load("@​bazel_tools//tools/build_defs/repo:http.bzl", "http_archive")
http_archive(
    name = "aspect_rules_ts",
    sha256 = "f60d5d25d17760e258d194f1fcab7a29e73629b86f070609c6ce2b2459dd49e3",
    strip_prefix = "rules_ts-3.6.2",
    url = "https://github.com/aspect-build/rules_ts/releases/download/v3.6.2/rules_ts-v3.6.2.tar.gz",
)

##################

### rules_ts setup #
##################

### Fetches the rules_ts dependencies.
### If you want to have a different version of some dependency,

### you should fetch it *before* calling this.
### Alternatively, you can skip calling this function, so long as you've

### already fetched all the dependencies.
load("@​aspect_rules_ts//ts:repositories.bzl", "rules_ts_dependencies")

rules_ts_dependencies(

### This keeps the TypeScript version in-sync with the editor, which is typically best.
    ts_version_from = "//:package.json",

### Alternatively, you could pick a specific version, or use
### load("@​aspect_rules_ts//ts:repositories.bzl", "LATEST_TYPESCRIPT_VERSION")

### ts_version = LATEST_TYPESCRIPT_VERSION
)

load("@​aspect_rules_js//js:repositories.bzl", "rules_js_dependencies")

rules_js_dependencies()

load("@​aspect_rules_js//js:toolchains.bzl", "DEFAULT_NODE_VERSION", "rules_js_register_toolchains")

rules_js_register_toolchains(node_version = DEFAULT_NODE_VERSION)

load("@​aspect_rules_js//npm:repositories.bzl", "npm_translate_lock")

npm_translate_lock(
    name = "npm",
    npmrc = "//:.npmrc",
    pnpm_lock = "//:pnpm-lock.yaml",
    verify_node_modules_ignored = "//:.bazelignore",
)

load("@​npm//:repositories.bzl", "npm_repositories")

npm_repositories()

### Register aspect_bazel_lib toolchains;
### If you use npm_translate_lock or npm_import from aspect_rules_js you can omit this block.
load("@​aspect_bazel_lib//lib:repositories.bzl", "aspect_bazel_lib_dependencies")

aspect_bazel_lib_dependencies()
```

To use rules\_ts with bazel-lib 2.x, you must additionally register the coreutils toolchain.

```starlark
load("@​aspect_bazel_lib//lib:repositories.bzl", "register_coreutils_toolchains")

register_coreutils_toolchains()
```

**Full Changelog**: https://github.com/aspect-build/rules\_ts/compare/v3.6.1...v3.6.2

</details>

```

To use rules\_ts with bazel-lib 2.x, you must additionally register the coreutils toolchain.

```starlark
load("@​aspect_bazel_lib//lib:repositories.bzl", "register_coreutils_toolchains")

register_coreutils_toolchains()
```

Issues.Title: Phantom component ngOnDestroy running (with no ngOnInit)
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

core

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

### Problem Description
When navigating between routes, particularly when the same component () is utilized across these routes with different `ActivatedRoute.snapshot.data` configurations, an lifecycle hook is observed to execute for a component instance that appears to be "phantom." This "phantom" instance's seems to operate using the `ActivatedRoute.snapshot.data` of the _new, incoming_ route, rather than the data that would have been relevant to its (unobserved or previous) initialization. `ProjectListPageComponent``ngOnDestroy``ngOnDestroy`

### Steps to Reproduce (Conceptual)
1. Navigate to a route that displays (let's call this Route A). `ProjectListPageComponent`
2. Navigate to a different component/route (Route B), which implicitly causes the from Route A to be destroyed. `ProjectListPageComponent`
3. From Route B, initiate a navigation to a third route (Route C) that _also_ displays , but with a different `ActivatedRoute.snapshot.data` context. `ProjectListPageComponent`
4. Observe console logs for and of , paying close attention to unique instance IDs. `ngOnDestroy``ngOnInit``ProjectListPageComponent`

### Observed Behavior
To precisely track the lifecycle of component instances and confirm this behavior, a unique was generated for each and logged during both and . The following sequence was consistently observed: `instanceId``ProjectListPageComponent``ngOnInit``ngOnDestroy`
- **Instance A (`ID: 717725`)**:
    - : Logs its creation, indicating its context from Route A. `ngOnInit`
    - : Logs its destruction, correctly reflecting its context from Route A. `ngOnDestroy`

- **Navigation to Route C occurs.**
- **Unexpected for Instance B (`ID: 910180`)`ngOnDestroy`**:
    - **Crucially, there was NO log observed for `ID: 910180` that would correspond to its creation within the context of Route C.`ngOnInit`** This instance appears as a "phantom" in the logs â€“ it seems to exist only at the point of destruction without a clear preceding initialization for the context it's operating on.
    - However, its fired. At this point, any internal logic within this that relies on `ActivatedRoute.snapshot.data` evaluated based on the data provided by Route C (the _new, incoming_ route), not the data of its original (or seemingly non-existent) context. `ngOnDestroy``ngOnDestroy`
    - This led to unintended actions, as the component's destruction logic acted on a context it was not initialized in.

- **New Instance C (`ID: 767872`)**:
    - : Logs its creation, correctly indicating it's in the context of Route C. `ngOnInit`

This demonstrates a critical timing issue: an is being invoked for a component instance (ID `910180`) that, based on logs, was never properly initialized for the context it then attempts to tear down. Furthermore, when this "phantom" runs, it is exposed to the `ActivatedRoute.snapshot.data` of the _new_ route (Route C), leading to incorrect conditional logic execution for that specific, out-of-context instance. `ngOnDestroy``ngOnInit``ngOnDestroy`

### Expected Behavior
A lifecycle hook should execute its internal logic, particularly when depending on `ActivatedRoute.snapshot.data`, using the data that was valid at the time the component instance was initially created (). Component instances that are not explicitly initialized for a certain route context should not execute destruction logic tied to that context, even if the Angular router's global state has advanced. `ngOnDestroy``ngOnInit``ActivatedRoute`

### Hypothesis
The issue likely stems from the order of operations during router transitions. It appears that the singleton service might update its to reflect the next, active route _before_ all hooks for components from the outgoing route have fully completed. This allows "dying" component instances to incorrectly read the future route's data. `ActivatedRoute``snapshot.data``ngOnDestroy`


### Please provide a link to a minimal reproduction of the bug

_No response_

### Please provide the exception or error you saw

```true

```

### Please provide the environment you discovered this bug in (run `ng version`)

```true

```

### Anything else?

Here's how this might occur, even with a clean navigation path:

1. **Asynchronous Router Cleanup / Zone.js Interaction:** Angular's router and change detection rely heavily on Zone.js and asynchronous task queues. It's possible that `ProjectListPage [ID: 910180]` was an instance that was created _extremely briefly_ (perhaps due to a rapid, internal, unobserved router event, or even a previous, quickly abandoned navigation to an route that wasn't fully cleaned up). If its destruction was queued asynchronously and only triggered later, it might appear in the logs at a seemingly illogical moment.

3. **Router's Internal Reconciliation:** When the Angular Router initiates a complex navigation, it performs an internal reconciliation. This process identifies which components need to be activated and which need to be deactivated/destroyed. If `910180` existed in the router's internal component tree (even if not actively rendered), this new navigation to _another_ (for `767872`) could have implicitly triggered the final destruction of the old `910180` instance as part of cleaning up the component pool for similar routes. 

`ProjectListPage [ID: 910180]`'s being called without any ngOnInit indicates that an instance of with that ID, was present in memory and was ultimately cleaned up by the Angular Router. It is likely an orphaned or lingering instance from a very brief, perhaps unnoticed, prior router state that was finally garbage collected as the router prepared for the creation of the new `ProjectListPageComponent [ID: 767872]`. 

If a component instance is truly being used and rendered by Angular, its lifecycle hook _should_ be called. The fact that I do not see an for `ngOnDestroy` for `ProjectListPage [ID: 910180]` but **no corresponding log for that exact ID`ngOnInit`** means one very important thing: 
**`ProjectListPage [ID: 910180]` was never fully initialized and rendered as an active component by Angular's change detection cycle.**

Why this happens?:
1. **Component Instantiation vs. Initialization:** Angular first _instantiates_ a component class (runs its `constructor`) and then, if that component is going to be part of the active view hierarchy, it proceeds to _initialize_ it by calling `ngOnInit` (after all inputs are bound). If a component is instantiated but then immediately discarded or superseded by another navigation before it's "set up" for rendering, `ngOnInit` might never be called.

3. **Rapid Router Transitions or Guards:**  - If there's a very quick succession of router events, or if a route guard immediately redirects before the target component can fully initialize, the component might be instantiated in memory only to be immediately abandoned.

3. **Internal Router Reconciliation/Optimization:** 
    - It's possible that `910180` was an internal, transient instance created during a router calculation or an aborted navigation attempt that was never actually put into the DOM and thus never triggered its . `ngOnInit`
    - When a new, similar route is activated (like navigating to for `767872`), the router might perform a cleanup pass, and `910180`â€”which was sitting in some internal stateâ€”is finally identified as "stale" and marked for destruction, leading to its `ngOnDestroy`being called.
   
The presence of `ngOnDestroy` without an `ngOnInit`for `ProjectListPage [ID: 910180]` is a strong indicator that this specific instance of the component was created internally by Angular (or the router), but it never reached the stage of being fully activated and rendered in the view. The `ngOnDestroy` log signifies that Angular's memory management eventually cleaned up this "un-initialized" component instance.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Phantom component ngOnDestroy running (with no ngOnInit)" (#62473)

Issues.Title: Blank page when serving app with @angular/localize i18n tags after upgrading to Angular 19.2.15
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are the source of the bug?

Don't known / other

### Is this a regression?

No

### Description

After upgrading our application from Angular 18 to Angular 19.2.15, we get a completely blank page when running ng serve. Removing all i18n tags allows the app to render normally, so it appears the problem lies with the @angular/localize library or its integration.

We havenâ€™t found any existing GitHub issue describing the same behavior, so any pointers to diagnose or fix this would be greatly appreciated!

**Whatâ€™s Working**

- No i18n tags: Removing all i18n attributes makes the app render correctly with no translations working.
- Non-English locales with **@ngx-env/builder**: `ng serve --ssl --configuration=es` works, and translations are applied correctly.

**Whatâ€™s Not Working**

- Default (English) locale with any builder: `@ngx-env/builder:dev-server `v^19.1.0 and `@angular-devkit/build-angular:dev-server` v19.2.15. Both produce a blank page when the appâ€™s templates include i18n tags.
- Changing sourceLocale from "**en**" to "**en-US**" in **angular.json** has no effect.
- Downgrading to **angular-localize** v^19.2.13
- main.ts contains this line at the begining but it has no effect: `/// <reference types="@angular/localize" />`

    "@angular/compiler-cli": "19.2.14",

Issues.Title: Support providing a space-separated list of classes when using [class] bindings
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request? core ### Description While migrating my app to Angular 20 and changing to the new control flow syntax, I thought I would also remove [ngClass] in favour of [class] The problem is that [class] does not support the way you usually add tailwind. ```html
``` ![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/66e7ed14-3ffd-44cf-af59-3bb9e96ec1b3) I think a lot of people (including myself) thought this would just work, and the path angular has been taking with removing the control flow directives, that you should prefer using [class] over [ngClass] I found this issue where it was said that it would not get fixed, which I can understand. https://github.com/angular/angular/issues/54605 But maybe there should be a disclaimer on [class] saying that the above does not work and you should use ngClass ### Proposed solution if angular is heading in the direction that [class] is going to be the preferred way of adding classes, we should reconsider adding the string splitting to [class] because of tailwinds success (and clsx) if not add a big note in the [class] documentation saying you need to use [ngClass] instead when writing the above. ### Alternatives considered just use ngClass
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Support providing a space-separated list of classes when using [class] bindings" (#62469)

Issues.Title: Support "selector" option for createComponent
Issues.Body:
### Which @angular/* package(s) are relevant/related to the feature request?

_No response_

### Description

Many UI libraries such as material has multiple selector for a specific component.

```
  selector: `
    button[matButton], a[matButton], button[mat-button], button[mat-raised-button],
    button[mat-flat-button], button[mat-stroked-button], a[mat-button], a[mat-raised-button],
    a[mat-flat-button], a[mat-stroked-button]
  `,
```

When using `createComponent(MatButton)` it will create it with the first selector and I have no way to specify a different one. In my specific use case I'd like to be able to create it as `a[mat-button]`.

### Proposed solution

Offer an extra field in the option or maybe have a new "Binding" function.

```
createComponent(MatButton, { selector: 'a[mat-button]' });

createComponent(MatButton, { bindings: [selectorBinding('a[mat-button]')] })
```

### Alternatives considered

Found no alternatives
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "Support "selector" option for createComponent" (#62458)

Issues.Title: fix(docs-infra): fix tutorial formatting issues (for v20)
Issues.Body:
This fixes multiple cases of wrong `visibleLines` values on `<docs-code>`  elements within the First-App tutorial pages on angular.dev site. 

> This is continuation of the work started in https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/61909

In many files the line numbers were off by 1, which is a result of shortening them with https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/58660, without updating docs to match that change. 


Additionally, some minor improvements within `first-app` and `learn-angular` tutorials were added 
 - all codeblocks normalized to 2 spaces indentation
 - lesson 14-http sEverely de-indented
 - descriptions and explanations were rewritten to reflect the changes from `@Input` to `input` and from `ngFor` to `@for`
 - missing step added in lesson 11-details-page
 - rewritten confusing instructions for adding code that was already added in previous steps

> A [sister PR for v19](https://github.com/angular/angular/pull/62451) branch was also prepared. 
> Sadly v19 doesn't accept further changes anymore, and without these fixes the v19 tutorials will remain in disarray.

Issues.Title: Angular CLI v20 generates incorrect component metadata (missing standalone, wrong styleUrls, class name)
Issues.Body:
### Command

new

### Is this a regression?

- [x] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

When generating a component using ng generate component <component_name> in Angular CLI v20, the output is structurally incorrect:

- **standalone: true** is missing

- **styleUrl** is used instead of **_styleUrls_** (invalid key)

- The **class** name omits the **_Component_** suffix


### Actual Output (src/app/test/test.ts)
```
@Component({
  selector: 'app-test',
  imports: [],
  templateUrl: './test.html',
  styleUrl: './test.css'
})
export class Test {}

```

### Expected Output 
```
@Component({
  selector: 'app-test',
  standalone: true,
  imports: [],
  templateUrl: './test.html',
  styleUrls: ['./test.css']
})
export class TestComponent {}
```

### Notes

- This behavior is consistent across multiple fresh projects
- It occurs even after resetting the environment using **nvm** and a fresh Angular CLI install.
- It prevents components from compiling correctly in a default Angular 20 standalone setup.

### Minimal Reproduction

1. ng new angular-cli-test --defaults
2. cd angular-cli-test
3. ng generate component test

### Exception or Error

```text

```

### Your Environment

```text
Angular CLI: 20.0.5
Angular: 20.0.5
Node: 20.19.3 (via nvm)
npm: 10.8.2
OS: macOS (arm64)
```

### Anything else relevant?

_No response_

Issues.Title: Excessive number of chunks in Angular downgrading performance
Issues.Body: ### Command new ### Is this a regression? - [x] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version ### The previous version in which this bug was not present was _No response_ ### Description I am not going to add many details as I see that this has been reported many times: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/26307 https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/27321 https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/27418 But I would say this should be address, there should be an option to configure the chunk strategy. When Angular was using Modules, and lazy routes the chunk strategy was simple based on lazy load modules. Now I think this has got out of hand, networks connection/devices are not the same for all users ### Minimal Reproduction Create a simple Angular app on version 17+ and observe the number of chunks. ### Exception or Error ```text ``` ### Your Environment ```text Angular CLI: 20.0.3 Node: 20.19.0 Package Manager: npm 10.8.2 OS: win32 x64 Angular: 20.0.4 ... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms ... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, platform-server ... router Package Version ------------------------------------------------------ @angular-devkit/architect 0.2000.3 @angular-devkit/core 20.0.3 (cli-only) @angular-devkit/schematics 20.0.3 @angular/build 20.0.3 @angular/cdk 20.0.3 @angular/cli 20.0.3 @angular/material 20.0.3 @angular/ssr 20.0.3 @schematics/angular 20.0.3 rxjs 7.8.2 typescript 5.8.3 zone.js 0.15.0 ``` ### Anything else relevant? @mgechev I recall you last time were calling for community suggested feature, considering the number of times this issue is appearing maybe this can be a feature to consider in the next release.

Issues.Title: build: update dependency aspect_rules_ts to v3.6.2
Issues.Body:
This PR contains the following updates:

| Package | Type | Update | Change |
|---|---|---|---|
| [aspect_rules_ts](https://redirect.github.com/aspect-build/rules_ts) | http_archive | patch | `v3.6.0` -> `v3.6.2` |

---

### Release Notes

<details>
<summary>aspect-build/rules_ts (aspect_rules_ts)</summary>

### [`v3.6.2`](https://redirect.github.com/aspect-build/rules_ts/releases/tag/v3.6.2)

[Compare Source](https://redirect.github.com/aspect-build/rules_ts/compare/v3.6.0...v3.6.2)

#### Using [Bzlmod]:

Add to your `MODULE.bazel` file:

```starlark
bazel_dep(name = "aspect_rules_ts", version = "3.6.2")

rules_ts_ext = use_extension("@​aspect_rules_ts//ts:extensions.bzl", "ext", dev_dependency = True)

rules_ts_ext.deps(
    ts_version_from = "//:package.json",
)

use_repo(rules_ts_ext, "npm_typescript")
```

[Bzlmod]: https://bazel.build/build/bzlmod

#### Using legacy WORKSPACE

Paste this snippet into your `WORKSPACE` file:

```starlark
load("@​bazel_tools//tools/build_defs/repo:http.bzl", "http_archive")
http_archive(
    name = "aspect_rules_ts",
    sha256 = "f60d5d25d17760e258d194f1fcab7a29e73629b86f070609c6ce2b2459dd49e3",
    strip_prefix = "rules_ts-3.6.2",
    url = "https://github.com/aspect-build/rules_ts/releases/download/v3.6.2/rules_ts-v3.6.2.tar.gz",
)

##################

### rules_ts setup #
##################

### Fetches the rules_ts dependencies.
### If you want to have a different version of some dependency,

### you should fetch it *before* calling this.
### Alternatively, you can skip calling this function, so long as you've

### already fetched all the dependencies.
load("@​aspect_rules_ts//ts:repositories.bzl", "rules_ts_dependencies")

rules_ts_dependencies(

### This keeps the TypeScript version in-sync with the editor, which is typically best.
    ts_version_from = "//:package.json",

### Alternatively, you could pick a specific version, or use
### load("@​aspect_rules_ts//ts:repositories.bzl", "LATEST_TYPESCRIPT_VERSION")

### ts_version = LATEST_TYPESCRIPT_VERSION
)

load("@​aspect_rules_js//js:repositories.bzl", "rules_js_dependencies")

rules_js_dependencies()

load("@​aspect_rules_js//js:toolchains.bzl", "DEFAULT_NODE_VERSION", "rules_js_register_toolchains")

rules_js_register_toolchains(node_version = DEFAULT_NODE_VERSION)

load("@​aspect_rules_js//npm:repositories.bzl", "npm_translate_lock")

npm_translate_lock(
    name = "npm",
    npmrc = "//:.npmrc",
    pnpm_lock = "//:pnpm-lock.yaml",
    verify_node_modules_ignored = "//:.bazelignore",
)

load("@​npm//:repositories.bzl", "npm_repositories")

npm_repositories()

### Register aspect_bazel_lib toolchains;
### If you use npm_translate_lock or npm_import from aspect_rules_js you can omit this block.
load("@​aspect_bazel_lib//lib:repositories.bzl", "aspect_bazel_lib_dependencies")

aspect_bazel_lib_dependencies()
```

To use rules\_ts with bazel-lib 2.x, you must additionally register the coreutils toolchain.

```starlark
load("@​aspect_bazel_lib//lib:repositories.bzl", "register_coreutils_toolchains")

register_coreutils_toolchains()
```

#### What's Changed

- chore: fix release\_prep reference to snippet in e2e/smoke/WORKSPACE by [@​jbedard](https://redirect.github.com/jbedard) in [https://github.com/aspect-build/rules_ts/pull/821](https://redirect.github.com/aspect-build/rules_ts/pull/821)1

**Full Changelog**: https://github.com/aspect-build/rules\_ts/compare/v3.6.1...v3.6.2

</details>

Issues.Title: Package subpath './src/builders/karma' is not defined by "exports"
Issues.Body: ### Command test ### Is this a regression? - [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version ### The previous version in which this bug was not present was _No response_ ### Description When trying to create a custom karma builder: ```ts import { createBuilder } from "@angular-devkit/architect"; import { execute as executeKarmaBuilder, KarmaBuilderOptions, } from "@angular/build/src/builders/karma"; export default createBuilder(executeKarmaBuilder); ``` The builder compiles successfully but I get this issue when trying to run it with `ng test`: ``` An unhandled exception occurred: Package subpath './src/builders/karma' is not defined by "exports" in /.../node_modules/@angular/build/package.json ``` The builder's execute function is marked experimental so I guess we should be able to use it (at my own risk), no? ### Minimal Reproduction Create a custom builder using the code above. ### Exception or Error ```text An unhandled exception occurred: Package subpath './src/builders/karma' is not defined by "exports" in /.../node_modules/@angular/build/package.json ``` ### Your Environment ```text Angular CLI: 20.0.5 Node: 22.15.0 Package Manager: npm 10.9.2 OS: darwin arm64 Angular: 20.0.6 ... common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms, localize ... platform-browser, platform-browser-dynamic, platform-server ... router Package Version --------------------------------------------------------- @angular-devkit/architect 0.2000.5 @angular-devkit/build-angular 20.0.5 @angular-devkit/core 20.0.5 @angular-devkit/schematics 20.0.5 @angular/build 20.0.5 @angular/cli 20.0.5 @angular/ssr 20.0.5 @schematics/angular 20.0.5 rxjs 7.8.2 ``` ### Anything else relevant? _No response_

Issues.Title: add config option to control async/await transpilation
Issues.Body:
### Command

build, run, e2e, serve, test

### Description

angular-cli introduced a heuristic to decide whether to transpile aync/await or use the native application.
since transpilation is necessary for zone.js, the heuristic executed transpilation if zone.js is added as polyfil or if any file with a file extension is added.

source: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/main/packages/angular/build/src/tools/esbuild/utils.ts#L477

Our angular app runs alongside other scripts which are not under our control. Therefore we separated zone.js from the angular bundle and instead import it manually as first script of the page (loading the angular bundle as first script is not an option).
Therefore we do not include zone.js in the polyfills array in angular.json.

Without the zone.js polyfills, the angular-cli does not transpile async/await which then results in broken change-detection as zone.js does not support native async/await.

### Describe the solution you'd like

A config option to force async/await transpilation independent of the content of the polyfills array.

This would give a solution for the problem of unwanted transpilation in zoneless applications (https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/issues/29853)

### Describe alternatives you've considered

As a workaround we are adding an empty javascript file to the polyfills array.

We considered changing our base page/integration setup such that the angular bundle is loaded first, but the impact on the overall architecture of the company-wide solution is too big.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "add config option to control async/await transpilation" (#30656)

Issues.Title: feat(@angular/build): allow enabling Bazel sandbox plugin with esbuild
Issues.Body:
## PR Checklist

Please check to confirm your PR fulfills the following requirements:

<!-- Please check all that apply using "x". -->

- [x] The commit message follows our guidelines: https://github.com/angular/angular-cli/blob/main/CONTRIBUTING.md#-commit-message-guidelines
- [ ] Tests for the changes have been added (for bug fixes / features)
- [ ] ~Docs have been added / updated (for bug fixes / features)~

*User facing documentation is intentionally omitted as this will be considered internal for now.*

## PR Type

What kind of change does this PR introduce?

<!-- Please check the one that applies to this PR using "x". -->

- [ ] Bugfix
- [x] Feature
- [ ] Code style update (formatting, local variables)
- [ ] Refactoring (no functional changes, no api changes)
- [ ] Build related changes
- [ ] CI related changes
- [ ] Documentation content changes
- [ ] Other... Please describe:

## What is the current behavior?

When trying to integrate the `esbuild` based builder into Bazel with `rules_js` we found that it will incorrectly follow symlinks out of the sandbox. This is because Node.js based tooling runs in the output tree to support canonical JS project directory structures. The output tree will contain symlinks outside of the sandbox. Node tooling will generally follow these symlinks, which violates the rules of Bazel sandboxing. This can manifest in a wide variety of errors. One example we encountered with Angular compilation is that the symlinked browser entry point (e.g. `main.ts`) is outside of the range of `tsconfig.json` when the compiler follows the symlink.

Issue Number: N/A

## What is the new behavior?

Setting the new `ENABLE_BAZEL_SANDBOX_PLUGIN` environment variable to `true` or `1` during a build with the `esbuild` based builder will now inject a special plugin to make `esbuild` compatible with Bazel builds in the output tree.

## Does this PR introduce a breaking change?

- [ ] Yes
- [x] No

<!-- If this PR contains a breaking change, please describe the impact and migration path for existing applications below. -->

## Other information

The plugin itself was originally written in https://github.com/aspect-build/rules_esbuild. The version container in this commit is a fork of https://github.com/aspect-build/rules_esbuild/blob/e4e49d3354cbf7087c47ac9c5f2e6fe7f5e398d3/esbuild/private/plugins/bazel-sandbox.js. I've adapted the JS file to TypeScript and made no further changes.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "feat(@angular/build): allow enabling Bazel sandbox plugin with esbuild" (#30654)

Issues.Title: fix(@angular/build): resolve "Controller is already closed" error in Karma
Issues.Body:
This issue stems from the `Some of your tests did a full page reload` error, which occurs because `karmaOptions.client.clearContext` is set to `true` when `singleRun` is `false`, even though Karma is running in watch mode. Previously, the `watch` flag was configured inconsistently across multiple locations, leading to misalignment.

Closes #30506
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open PR "fix(@angular/build): resolve "Controller is already closed" error in Karma" (#30653)

Issues.Title: Allow restarting Angular proxy server without restarting the full dev server
Issues.Body:
Command
- serve

### Description
Currently, when using Angular CLI's development server with a proxy configuration, any change to the proxy or interruption (such as backend server restarts) requires stopping and restarting the entire dev server. This is disruptive to the development flow, especially when only the proxy needs to be reloaded or reconnected.

### Describe the solution you'd like
Provide a way to restart just the proxy server without stopping the entire Angular dev server. This could be through a dedicated CLI command (e.g., `ng serve --restart-proxy`), a watch mode that only restarts the proxy on config change, or a single pressing to restart it manually just like following picture:

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/c4478d0a-3750-4288-b042-a5a3944dbc48)


This feature would streamline development involving backend APIs and reduce context-switching for developers.

> Created via github copilot agent.
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed issue "Allow restarting Angular proxy server without restarting the full dev server" (#30650)

Issues.Title: Regression: Karma fails to proxy /base/base/base/base/base...
Issues.Body: ### Command test ### Is this a regression? - [x] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version ### The previous version in which this bug was not present was 20.0.4 ### Description When running tests with Karma, using the default configuration, we now get plenty of warning messages in the console looking like this: ``` 02 07 2025 12:18:05.513:WARN [proxy]: failed to proxy -Regular.woff (socket hang up) ``` or ``` 02 07 2025 12:11:11.751:WARN [proxy]: failed to proxy .webp (socket hang up) ``` This thus happens both for media assets (i.e. resources such as fonts referenced by scss stylesheets and copied to the media folder by the CLI) and for public assets (i.e. files located in the `public` directory, such as images used in `` elements of the templates). ### Minimal Reproduction See https://github.com/jnizet/karma-repro Steps: - `git clone git@github.com:jnizet/karma-repro.git` - `cd karma-repro` - `npm i` - `ng test --no-watch` Or run it into stackblitz: https://stackblitz.com/~/github.com/jnizet/karma-repro ### Exception or Error Lots of warnings looking like this, with various nesting levels of `/base` ```text 03 07 2025 08:55:10.035:WARN [proxy]: failed to proxy /base/base/images/angular/ebook-cover.webp (socket hang up) ``` ### Your Environment ```text Angular CLI: 20.0.5 Node: 22.16.0 Package Manager: pnpm 10.12.4 OS: darwin x64 Angular: 20.0.6 ... animations, common, compiler, compiler-cli, core, forms ... localize, platform-browser, platform-server, router Package Version ------------------------------------------------------ @angular-devkit/architect 0.2000.5 (cli-only) @angular-devkit/core 20.0.5 (cli-only) @angular-devkit/schematics 20.0.5 (cli-only) @angular/build 20.0.5 @angular/cli 20.0.5 @angular/ssr 20.0.5 @schematics/angular 20.0.5 (cli-only) rxjs 7.8.2 typescript 5.8.3 zone.js 0.15.1 ``` ### Anything else relevant? _No response_

Issues.Title: fix(@angular/build): correctly remap Angular diagnostics
Issues.Body:
The esbuild builder has some logic that re-maps diagnostics coming from the compiler, depending on their `source` and `code`. Currently this is incorrect, because it assumes that a value of `ngtsc` for `source` always means that the error is from the Angular compiler, but what it actually means is that it comes from an Angular template diagnostics. Furthermore, we can't rely on a `source` always being defined.

These changes align the logic to a similar one we already have in the compiler where we assume the diagnostic comes from Angular if it starts with `-99`.

Issues.Title: fix(@angular/build): proxy karma request from `/` to `/base`
Issues.Body:
This commit fixes an issue where Karma requests were not being correctly proxied, leading to 404 errors for assets and other files during test execution in Angular projects. The fix ensures that all Karma requests from the root (`/`) are correctly forwarded to the `/base` directory, where Karma serves the files.

Karma will always serve files from `/base`. This change aligns the testing environment with this fundamental behavior, resolving pathing issues and ensuring that tests can locate their dependencies reliably.

Closes #30627
Issues.RelatedDescription: Closed or merged PR "fix(@angular/build): proxy karma request from `/` to `/base`" (#30632)

Issues.Title: bug(MatTabs): Touch Delayed on Mobile
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

With MatTab tab switching, there exists a delay on mobile devices and in the Chrome mobile emulation dev mode. This is 100% reproducible on the standard documentation page: https://material.angular.dev/components/tabs/overview

Users found that our WebApp has a sluggish delay when switching between MatTabs and I thought there was some issue with the way we load our components, but no: It turns out there is an underlying issue with how Mat Tabs are. Demonstrated in this video, there is a delay.

https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/3376d4c4-9f3d-4a1d-ba89-c480e5266231

On chrome, until the tab starts to animate, it takes **~100ms** from the moment of click. But in Mobile Device Emulation mode, you can see that it takes 3 times as long, roughly **~330ms**. This is a bit worse on real iPad hardware, where it take up to **~400ms**, feeling seriously sluggish.

I think this to be a regression, related to https://stackoverflow.com/questions/39902055/web-app-feels-less-responsive-when-added-to-iphones-home-screen

### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: 
Steps to reproduce:
1. 
2.


### Expected Behavior

The delay when interacting with Mat Tabs should be the same when using touch, as when using the mouse.

### Actual Behavior

There seems to be a 300ms delay, specifically with MatTabs

### Environment

- Angular: 19
- CDK/Material: 19
- Browser(s): Chrome, Safari
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): Windows, iPad OS
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(MatTabs): Touch Delayed on Mobile" (#31488)

Issues.Title: bug(datepicker): VoiceOver on iOS Fails to Announce Day of Week in Angular Material Datepicker, Violating WCAG 1.3.1
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

The Angular Material Datepicker does not announce the day of the week (which is present in the table header) when using VoiceOver on iOS. Currently, VoiceOver reads the selected date as â€œJuly 3rd, 2025, row X, column X,â€ but omits the associated day of the week.

This behavior does not meet [WCAG 2.1 Success Criterion 1.3.1: Info and Relationships (Level A)](https://www.w3.org/WAI/WCAG21/Understanding/info-and-relationships.html), as the relationship between the date and its corresponding day of the week is not conveyed to assistive technologies.

### Reproduction

Steps to Reproduce

1. Enable VoiceOver via Settings > Accessibility > VoiceOver
2. Open Safari on an iOS device.
3. Navigate to the Angular Material Datepicker demo page:https://material.angular.dev/components/datepicker/overview
4. Open the datepicker by selecting any of the date input fields.
5. Use VoiceOver to navigate through the calendar and select a date.
6. The VoiceOver does not read the Day of the Week.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/a2238c7b-40e8-4956-b879-486c1616ad32)

### Expected Behavior

VoiceOver should announce the full date, including the day of the week.

### Actual Behavior

VoiceOver only reads the date and position (e.g., "July 3rd, 2025, row X, column X") but does not announce the day of the week, which is visually present in the table header.

### Environment

- Angular: 18, 20
- CDK/Material: 18, 20
- Browser(s): Safari
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): iOS
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(datepicker): VoiceOver on iOS Fails to Announce Day of Week in Angular Material Datepicker, Violating WCAG 1.3.1" (#31480)

Issues.Title: bug(form-field): label-offset-x is incorrectly computed when there is a prefix
Issues.Body: ### Is this a regression? - [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version ### The previous version in which this bug was not present was _No response_ ### Description Inside `_mdc-text-field-structure-overrides.scss` https://github.com/angular/components/blob/7bb0a82a434c40d01a0d1aa35bcddaa3f725eccb/src/material/form-field/_mdc-text-field-structure-overrides.scss#L97 We can see that the variable `--mat-mdc-form-field-label-offset-x` is hardcoded to -16px (I guess it's coming from the fact that out of the box, form-field have a left-padding of 16px). But for outlined form field, the left-padding could get bigger in some cases when using a large value for the border-radius. This is because the left-padding is defined with `max(16px, var(--mdc-outlined-text-field-container-shape) + 4px)` So if I want my outlined form-fields to be rounded like a pill, I have to override the border-radius with this ``` @include mat.form-field-overrides(( outlined-container-shape: 28px, )) ``` Which will set the left-padding to 32px and not 16px. At this point everything looks good, and the label is correctly placed (when empty, it's aligned with the input value/placeholder) But things start to break when you add a prefix as it will `translateX` the label to make room for the prefix. This transform is based on the hardcoded value of `--mat-mdc-form-field-label-offset-x: -16px;`, so it works great for out-of-the-box form-field, but doesn't work for my pill form-field. Because the padding is set to 32px, the `--mat-mdc-form-field-label-offset-x` should be -32px and not -16px. So I end up with this: As you can see, the empty pill form-field's label isn't aligned anymore with where the input's value is. I know this can be fixed by overriding the `--mat-mdc-form-field-label-offset-x` myself by using `::ng-deep` to override the hardcoded value, but it's not something trivial to understand and fix, so I'd rather see a fix in the Angular Material repository. ### Reproduction https://stackblitz.com/edit/tk7fhpq7-w7dz4vdj?file=src%2Fexample%2Fform-field.scss ### Expected Behavior The label should be correctly placed when using a large border-radius value for outlined form-field, like the input value is. I believe the solution would be to change this line of code: ```diff - --mat-mdc-form-field-label-offset-x: -16px; + --mat-mdc-form-field-label-offset-x: max(16px, var(--mdc-outlined-text-field-container-shape, var(--mat-sys-corner-extra-small)) + 4px) * -1; ``` By the way, it would be nice to be able to control the "minimum" left & right padding to something else than the hardcoded 16px too ðŸ˜… ### Actual Behavior The label is not correctly aligned. ### Environment - Angular: 20.0.4 - CDK/Material: 20.0.4 - Browser(s): Chrome 137 - Operating System: macOS
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(form-field): label-offset-x is incorrectly computed when there is a prefix" (#31479)

The nested menu is placed over the origin menu, hiding the traingles.

Issues.Title: bug(button): overriding not working as expected.
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

To override the background color for a button to a particular hex value provided, the state layer needs to be given an opacity of value 1. However, in doing so, the outline is no longer clearly visible. It appears to get hidden behind the state layer/ ::before pseudo element created.



### Reproduction

StackBlitz link: https://stackblitz.com/edit/wwtmsk43?file=src%2Fexample%2Fbutton-overview-example.css

Hover over the outline button to notice the outline no longer being visible.

### Expected Behavior

When opacity for the state layer is set to 1, the state layer for an outlined button should not hide the outline for the button. The outline should still be visible.

### Actual Behavior

The background's stacking context is higher than the button's stacking context which is hiding the border/ outline.

### Environment

- Angular: 20
- CDK/Material: 20
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(button): overriding not working as expected." (#31475)

Issues.Title: bug(datepicker): Focus Not Properly Managed After Selecting Date in Angular Datepicker (VoiceOver, iOS)
Issues.Body:
### Is this a regression?

- [ ] Yes, this behavior used to work in the previous version

### The previous version in which this bug was not present was

_No response_

### Description

The Angular date picker doesn't properly focus on the selected date when using VoiceOver on iOS. When I try to select a date, the calendar opens as expected, and I double-tap to choose a date using VoiceOver. However, after the date is selected, the double-tap also triggers a selection on whatever element is behind the calendar. 

### Reproduction

Steps to reproduce:
1. Enable VoiceOver on iOS.
2. Navigate to [Angular Material Datepicker](https://material.angular.dev/components/datepicker/overview).
3. Open the datepicker; the calendar overlay appears.
4. Using VoiceOver, double-tap to select a date.
5. After the double-tap, focus unexpectedly shifts to an element behind the calendar instead of remaining within the datepicker.

![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/11398383-94a4-460f-9dee-f95fc38168d8)
![Image](https://github.com/user-attachments/assets/30798904-31a7-4d81-9442-4743afa04e8b)


### Expected Behavior

After selecting a date using VoiceOver, the focus should return to the datepicker input, not shift to elements behind the calendar.


### Actual Behavior

After selecting a date with VoiceOver, the focus shifts to an element behind the calendar instead of returning to the datepicker input.


### Environment

- Angular: 18, 20
- CDK/Material: 18, 20
- Browser(s): Safari, Chrome, Brave
- Operating System (e.g. Windows, macOS, Ubuntu): iOS
Issues.RelatedDescription: Open issue "bug(datepicker): Focus Not Properly Managed After Selecting Date in Angular Datepicker (VoiceOver, iOS)" (#31473)
